child.pub-comments: AUSTLANG classifies Guwij as a dialect of Ungarinyin (2011). "Nowadays more or less equated with Wurla" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 1). "Present number and distribution of speakers: Not known" (McGregor 1988: 112).

child.alt-names: Ungarinyin, Ngarinjin, Ungarinjin, Molyamidi, Wol'jamidi, Yamandil, Narrinyind, Gular, Unŋarinjin, Warnarinjin, Angarinjin, Wangarinjinu, Arawari, Ingarinjindja, Njingarinjanja, Arkarin-jindja, Oladjau, Marangana, Walmidi, Andedja, Andidja, Ungarin-jen, Ngaring-ngyan, Ngerringun, Kandjalngari
child.pub-comments: "c. 100 speakers" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 1). "According to Rumsey (1982:vii), the name of the language is Ungarinyin, Ngarinyin being the name of the people. The shorter form Ngarinyin, however, seems to have gained currency" (McGregor 1988: 98).

child.pub-comments: "Mainly in Wyndham and surrounding stations and communities, including Fork Creek, and Oombulgari. No estimates of numbers of speakers are known" (McGregor 1988: 108).

child.pub-comments: "Two Fluent Speakers" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 1). "Present number and distribution of speakers: Unknown" (McGregor 1988: 104).

"Throughout Chapters 3 to 7 we identified a number of grammatical innovations characteristic of each of the three postulated groups, Northern, Eastern, and Western... This tabulation reveals that a number of innovations support the positing of Northern and Western groups, while support for the Eastern group is rather weaker. Nevertheless, we submit that the evidence is sufficient to justify the three primary groupings as genetic subgroups of Worrorran" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 75).

child.pub-comments: "A few speakers" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 1). "Figure 3 shows the locations of the Worrorran languages, and indicates how the proposed subgroups are distributed geographically. Observe in particular that the groups are geographically contiguous" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 7). Figure 3 is a map where Gulunggulu is tentatively placed with the Northern Worrorran languages (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 8). "Worrorran family, subgroup unknown, but possibly Wunambalic" (McGregor 1988: 125).

"Throughout Chapters 3 to 7 we identified a number of grammatical innovations characteristic of each of the three postulated groups, Northern, Eastern, and Western... This tabulation reveals that a number of innovations support the positing of Northern and Western groups, while support for the Eastern group is rather weaker. Nevertheless, we submit that the evidence is sufficient to justify the three primary groupings as genetic subgroups of Worrorran" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 75). "Present number and distribution of speakers: Wyndham area. Glasgow et al. -- up to 500 speakers (late 1960s)" (McGregor 1988: 129).

child.pub-comments: "Moribund" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 1). "There is reportedly at least one speaker in Mowanjum" (McGregor 1988: 90).

child.pub-comments: "Moribund" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 2). "Traditionally of the Montgomery Islands; now extinct (the last full speaker died in early 1987), although there reamin some part speakers, and a few Worrorra people who can understand the language" (McGregor 1988: 96).

child.pub-comments: "No surviving speakers" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 2). "Presumably extinct" (McGregor 1988: 94).

child.pub-comments: "Moribund" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 2). "There is one remaining full speaker, and a number of part speakers, living in Derby" (McGregor 1988: 92).

"Throughout Chapters 3 to 7 we identified a number of grammatical innovations characteristic of each of the three postulated groups, Northern, Eastern, and Western... This tabulation reveals that a number of innovations support the positing of Northern and Western groups, while support for the Eastern group is rather weaker. Nevertheless, we submit that the evidence is sufficient to justify the three primary groupings as genetic subgroups of Worrorran" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 75).

root.pub-comments: "The term Worrorran - Wororan in O'Grady, Voegelin and Voegelin (1966) - refers to a group of over twenty named language varieties tradiationally spoken throughout the Northern Kimberley region, which correspondes roughly with the Kimberley Block, a geological division consisting of some 180,000 square kilometers of mainly sandstone plateau" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 1). "Throughout Chapters 3 to 7 we identified a number of grammatical innovations characteristic of each of the three postulated groups, Northern, Eastern, and Western... This tabulation reveals that a number of innovations support the positing of Northern and Western groups, while support for the Eastern group is rather weaker. Nevertheless, we submit that the evidence is sufficient to justify the three primary groupings as genetic subgroups of Worrorran" (McGregor and Rumsey 2009: 75).
